title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: [[Category:2021 in American politics]]

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: ===Utah===

Gov. Spencer Cox had declared a state of emergency and asked Utah National Guard, highway patrol, and local police departments to "stand ready to ensure the safety of lives and property at Utah's Capitol".<ref>https://kutv.com/news/local/state-of-emergency-declared-in-utah-in-anticipation-of-inauguration-protests</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: Cleveland, as another major city in Ohio, announced it would close all nonemergency municipal buildings downtown, including its city hall, ahead of the protests.<ref>https://fox8.com/news/cleveland-closing-city-hall-other-downtown-city-buildings-friday-through-wednesday/</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: Cleveland, another major city in Ohio, announced it would close all nonemergency municipal buildings downtown, including its city hall, ahead of the protests.<ref>https://fox8.com/news/cleveland-closing-city-hall-other-downtown-city-buildings-friday-through-wednesday/</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: State capitol buildings are being prepared for violent protests, with temporary fencing and other security measures. The National Guard has been activated for at least 19 states.<ref name="NYT-1-17"/>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: ===Alabama===

Law enforcement officials expect protests in Montgomery, and have closed several downtown streets ahead of the protests. Police suggest businesses should allow workers to work remotely if possible.<ref>https://www.wsfa.com/2021/01/15/some-downtown-montgomery-streets-closing-protest-precautions/</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: Law enforcement officials expect protests in Montgomery, and have closed several downtown streets ahead of the protests. Police suggest businesses should allow workers to work remotely if possible.<ref>https://www.wsfa.com/2021/01/15/some-downtown-montgomery-streets-closing-protest-precautions/</ref> As of January 12, the state had no plan to increase security, though state police are monitoring issues of public safety.<ref name="USA Today">https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/2021/01/17/us-state-capitol-protests-washington-dc-live-updates/6654912002/#chapter36</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
deleted: {{merge to|2021 United States state capitol protests|discuss=Talk:2021 United States state capitol protests#Merger proposal|date=January 2021}}

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: ===Arkansas===
State officials in Arkansas have not found specific threats, though have provided additional state police to guard the capitol building.<ref name="USA Today"/>
===Colorado===

State police are aware of two protests approaching, and is monitoring the situation and planning security measures. The state is not specifying its response due to safety concerns.<ref name="USA Today"/>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: ===Idaho===

Boise Police Chief Ryan Lee announced that there wasn't "any info on any planned criminal acts" at the [[Idaho State Capitol]] in [[Boise, Idaho|Boise]]. However as a precaution, local law enforcement would be increasing patrols in downtown Boise.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ktvb.com/article/news/local/idaho-statehouse-protest-preparations-inauguration/277-aecc60cb-fedb-4df8-b38d-46ec7fc68879|title=Boise Police Chief Lee says local law enforcement doesn't have any info on any 'planned criminal acts'|work=KTVB|date=January 15, 2021|accessdate=January 17, 2021}}</ref>
===Kansas===

Governor [[Laura Kelly]] announced increased security measures at the [[Kansas State Capitol]] in [[Topeka, Kansas|Topeka]] as a response to planned pro-Trump violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wibw.com/2021/01/14/kansas-statehouse-releases-security-guidelines-in-response-to-inauguration-protests/|title=Kansas Statehouse releases security guidelines in response to inauguration protests|date=January 14, 2020|accessdate=January 17, 2020|work=WIBW|author=Motter, Sarah}}</ref>
===Kentucky===

The FBI released statements warning that pro-Trump protests at the [[Kentucky State Capitol]] building in [[Frankfort, Kentucky|Frankfort]] could turn violent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wymt.com/2021/01/14/kentucky-state-police-preparing-for-potential-kentucky-capitol-protests-ahead-of-presidential-inauguration/|title=Kentucky State Police preparing for potential Kentucky capitol protests ahead of presidential inauguration|date=January 14, 2020|accessdate=January 17, 2020|work=WYMT|author=Pendleton, Phil}}</ref>
===Nevada===

Authorities began receiving threats against the [[Nevada State Capitol]] building following the storming of the U.S. Capitol building; [[Nevada National Guard]] assembled units to support security forces at the Capitol building in response.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/2021/01/14/nevada-state-capitol-security-protets-biden-inauguration-day/6639586002/|title=Nevada law enforcement working to ensure security at state Capitol ahead of inauguration|work=[[Reno Gazette Journal]]|author=Wilkins, Terell|date=January 14, 2021|accessdate=January 17, 2021}}</ref>
===Oklahoma===

Oklahoma state lawmakers ordered increased security measures and police presence at the [[Oklahoma State Capitol]] building in [[Oklahoma City]] after reports of planned armed protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kfor.com/news/local/officials-step-up-security-at-oklahoma-state-capitol/|title=Officials step up security at Oklahoma State Capitol|date=January 12, 2020|accessdate=January 17, 2020|work=KFOR-TV|author=Skarky, Brent}}<ref> Governor [[Kevin Stitt]] later announced that members of the [[Oklahoma National Guard]] would be activated at the Oklahoma State Capitol from January 16 to January 17 to prevent potential violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.koco.com/article/gov-stitt-activates-oklahoma-national-guard-at-state-capitol-due-to-potential-protests/35227707#|title=Gov. Stitt activates Oklahoma National Guard at state Capitol due to potential protests|work=KOCO-5|author=Staff, KOCO|date=January 15, 2021|accessdate=January 17, 2021}}</ref>
===Virginia===

On January 15, 2021, a bomb threat was received at the [[Virginia Supreme Court]] building.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsls.com/news/2021/01/15/bomb-threat-prompts-evacuation-of-virginia-supreme-court-building/|title=Police allow people to re-enter Virginia Supreme Court building after bomb threat|date=January 15, 2021|accessdate=January 17, 2021|work=WSLS|author=Williamson, Jeff}}</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: ===New Mexico===

On January 17, Couy Griffin, a county commissioner in [[Otero County, New Mexico]], and founder of the "Cowboys for Trump" group, was arrested in Washington, D.C. Griffin had participated in the January 6 Capitol riot and had vowed to return to D.C. for the inauguration, armed with guns, and to hold a rally that would end with "blood running out of" the Capitol. Griffin was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building without lawful authority.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=January 17, 2021|title=New Mexico County Commissioner Arrested in DC for Involvement in Capitol Riot|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/new-mexico-county-commissioner-arrested-in-dc-for-involvement-in-capitol-riot/2544645/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210118130643/https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/new-mexico-county-commissioner-arrested-in-dc-for-involvement-in-capitol-riot/2544645/|archive-date=January 18, 2021|access-date=January 19, 2021|website=NBC4 Washington|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests

Griffin had participated in the January 6 Capitol riot and had vowed to return to D.C. for the inauguration, armed with guns, and to hold a rally that would end with "blood running out of" the Capitol. Griffin was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building without lawful authority.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=January 17, 2021|title=New Mexico County Commissioner Arrested in DC for Involvement in Capitol Riot|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/new-mexico-county-commissioner-arrested-in-dc-for-involvement-in-capitol-riot/2544645/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210118130643/https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/new-mexico-county-commissioner-arrested-in-dc-for-involvement-in-capitol-riot/2544645/|archive-date=January 18, 2021|access-date=January 19, 2021|website=NBC4 Washington|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: * [[Inauguration of Joe Biden]]

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: On January 17, a 22-year-old avowed Trump supporter from [[Gordonsville, Virginia]], was arrested near the Capitol complex, carrying a [[Glock 22]] handgun, three [[high-capacity magazine]]s, and 37 rounds of unregistered ammunition. The man was arrested on charges of carrying a pistol without a license, possessing a large-capacity ammunition feeding device, and possessing unregistered ammunition.<ref name="ManWoman">{{Cite web|last=Meckler|first=Laura|date=January 17, 2021|title=Avowed Trump supporter arrested near Capitol for carrying gun; women charged with impersonating police|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/capitol-security-zone-arrests/2021/01/17/41c60318-58e2-11eb-a976-bad6431e03e2_story.html|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210118000557/https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/capitol-security-zone-arrests/2021/01/17/41c60318-58e2-11eb-a976-bad6431e03e2_story.html|archive-date=January 18, 2021|access-date=January 18, 2021|website=[[Washington Post]]}}</ref> In a separate incident the same day,<ref name=ManWoman/> a 63-year-old woman from [[Stratford, Connecticut]], claimed to be a law enforcement officer and "a part of the presidential cabinet" after being stopped by Capitol Police at a checkpoint near Union Station; she fled from police before she was arrested.<ref name="Imperson2">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=January 17, 2021|title=Woman Arrested at Inauguration Checkpoint Said She Was Officer, Cabinet Member: Police|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/woman-arrested-at-inauguration-checkpoint-said-she-was-officer-cabinet-member-police/2544325/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210118155239/https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/woman-arrested-at-inauguration-checkpoint-said-she-was-officer-cabinet-member-police/2544325/|archive-date=January 18, 2021|access-date=January 19, 2021|website=NBC4 Washington|language=en-US}}</ref> The woman underwent a psychiatric examination,<ref name="Imperson2" /> and was subsequently charged with [[Police impersonation|impersonating a law enforcement officer]], failing to obey an officer, and fleeing an officer.<ref name=ManWoman/>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: After the inauguration, acting [[United States Capitol Police|U.S. Capitol Police]] chief [[Yogananda Pittman]] said that permanent fencing was needed around the U.S. Capitol.<ref>{{Cite web|title=After Riot, Acting Capitol Police Chief Calls For Permanent Fencing Around Complex|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/insurrection-at-the-capitol/2021/01/28/961673288/after-riot-acting-capitol-police-chief-calls-for-permanent-fencing-around-comple|access-date=2021-02-02|website=NPR.org|language=en}}</ref> This idea was controversial, and [[Mayor of the District of Columbia|DC Mayor]] [[Muriel Bowser]] and some politicians in both parties objected.<ref>{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=Daniella Diaz and Manu Raju|title=Proposal to build permanent fence around the Capitol meets resistance|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/28/politics/capitol-attack-permanent-fence-police/index.html|access-date=2021-02-02|website=CNN}}</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: ===Kentucky State Capitol armed protest===

The largest protest of Trump supporters that would take place in the subsequent weeks, and leading up to Biden's inauguration, had already occurred in Kentucky – prior to the January 11 FBI memo. In [[Frankfort, Kentucky|Frankfort]], on January 9, approximately 100 heavily armed protesters assembled for a "patriot rally" outside the [[Kentucky State Capitol]] while both chambers of the [[Kentucky General Assembly|General Assembly]] were in session. One of the armed protesters was wearing camouflage from head to toe and carrying several [[zip ties]], explaining that he brought them "just in case." Some of the protesters carried militia flags, pro-Trump insignia, and [[Three Percenters]] symbols. "Three days after [[Domestic terrorism in the United States|domestic terrorists]] attacked our U.S. Capitol, there was a militia rally in Frankfort. They brought zip ties. We will not be intimidated", Governor [[Andy Beshear]] tweeted in response.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Beer|first=Tommy|title=Heavily Armed Protesters Gather Outside Kentucky Capitol For Militia Rally|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tommybeer/2021/01/09/heavily-armed-protesters-gather-outside-kentucky-capitol-for-militia-rally/|access-date=2021-01-10|website=Forbes|language=en}}</ref>

title: 2021 United States inauguration week protests
added: About 270 [[Kentucky National Guard]] members were sent to the Washington D.C. in the week, to assist security operations. Dozens of state police and National Guard members were stationed in Frankfort on January 17, when only 2 armed members of bogaloo movement and 15 armed pro-BLM counter-protesters appeared in the proximity of the [[Kentucky state capitol|state capitol building]]. Police vehicles surrounded the building, limiting access to it. {{Citation needed}}
